item.title: Fraction Calculator Challenge
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:59, topic:547684”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=666588.msg4460063#msg4460063 date=1417057367]

What part of it looks like Javascript? And yes, it is similar to Java and compiles into Java bytecode.

This does

var firstFraction = (1,1);
var opIndex:String = _;
var secondFraction = (1,1); 
var scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

[/quote]
Scala doesn’t need to be told what type everything is (twice, since I already gave it the datatype on the right side), and apart from that it is nothing like the horrible language called Javascript.[/quote]

JS is fuckin hot m8

item.title: Fraction Calculator Challenge
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:55, topic:547684”]Am I good enough for you wildskiller? It is shorter than your’s and in my opinion cleaner. Sure the reduce method could be more efficient, but I could be bothered with that.

[code=scala]import java.util.Scanner
import java.lang.Exception

object Fractions extends App {
var firstFraction = (1,1);
var opIndex:String = _;
var secondFraction = (1,1);
var scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

println("This Console Program is meant to calculate FRACTIONS based on your selected index");
while(true){
	try{println("Write the first fraction in this format \"a/b\" without \"s.");
	firstFraction = scanner.next();
	println("Write 0 for addition. 1 for substraction, 2 for multiplication and 3 for division");
	opIndex = scanner.next();
	println("Write the second fraction in this format \"a/b\" without \"s");
	secondFraction = scanner.next();
	println(combineFraction(calculate(opIndex)(firstFraction,secondFraction)));
	}catch{
	case e:NumberFormatException => println("Please write the fraction in the current way \"a/b\".")
	case e:Exception => println(e.getMessage())
	}
}
scanner.close();
implicit def splitFraction(input:String):(Int,Int) ={
	val array = input.split("/");
	if(array.length != 2) throw new Exception("Please write the fraction in the current way \"a/b\".")
	return (array(0).toInt,array(1).toInt);
}

def combineFraction(arg0:(Int,Int)):String = {
	val output = reduce(arg0);
	return output._1 + "/" + output._2;
}

implicit def calculate(op:String):(((Int,Int),(Int,Int))=>(Int,Int)) = {
	op match {
	case "0" => return add;
	case "1" => return sub;
	case "2" => return mul;
	case "3" => return div;
	case _ => throw new Exception("Operator index must be from 0 to 3.");
	}
}

def add(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._2 + arg0._1 * arg0._2 , arg0._2 * arg1._2);
}
def sub(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._2 - arg0._1 * arg0._2 , arg0._2 * arg1._2);
}
def mul(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._1, arg0._2 * arg1._2);
}
def div(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._2, arg0._2 * arg1._1);
}

def reduce(arg0:(Int,Int)):(Int,Int) = {
	val min = Math.min(arg0._1, arg0._2);
	var i = 0;
	for(i <- min until 1 by -1){
		if(arg0._1 % i == 0 && arg0._2 % i == 0){
			return (arg0._1 / i, arg0._2 / i);
		}
	}
	return arg0;
}

} [/code][/quote]
Mine would be shorter if I used Python or Ruby, but I decided to use Java. I’ve never used Scala but it looks like JavaScript and Java put together. I agree though, yours is shorter and cleaner.

Read full topic

item.title: Fraction Calculator Challenge
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Am I good enough for you wildskiller? It is shorter than your’s and in my opinion cleaner. Sure the reduce method could be more efficient, but I could be bothered with that.

[code=scala]import java.util.Scanner
import java.util.Scanner
import java.lang.Exception

object Fractions extends App {
var firstFraction = (1,1);
var opIndex:String = _;
var secondFraction = (1,1);
var scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

println("This Console Program is meant to calculate FRACTIONS based on your selected index");
while(true){
	try{println("Write the first fraction in this format \"a/b\" without \"s.");
	firstFraction = scanner.next();
	println("Write 0 for addition. 1 for substraction, 2 for multiplication and 3 for division");
	opIndex = scanner.next();
	println("Write the second fraction in this format \"a/b\" without \"s");
	secondFraction = scanner.next();
	println(combineFraction(calculate(opIndex)(firstFraction,secondFraction)));
	}catch{
	case e:NumberFormatException => println("Please write the fraction in the current way \"a/b\".")
	case e:Exception => println(e.getMessage())
	}
}
scanner.close();
implicit def splitFraction(input:String):(Int,Int) ={
	val array = input.split("/");
	if(array.length != 2) throw new Exception("Please write the fraction in the current way \"a/b\".")
	return (array(0).toInt,array(1).toInt);
}

def combineFraction(arg0:(Int,Int)):String = {
	val output = reduce(arg0);
	return output._1 + "/" + output._2;
}

def calculate(op:String):(((Int,Int),(Int,Int))=>(Int,Int)) = {
	op match {
	case "0" => return add;
	case "1" => return sub;
	case "2" => return mul;
	case "3" => return div;
	case _ => throw new Exception("Operator index must be from 0 to 3.");
	}
}

def add(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._2 + arg0._1 * arg0._2 , arg0._2 * arg1._2);
}
def sub(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._2 - arg0._1 * arg0._2 , arg0._2 * arg1._2);
}
def mul(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._1, arg0._2 * arg1._2);
}
def div(arg0:(Int,Int),arg1:(Int,Int)) = {
	(arg0._1 * arg1._2, arg0._2 * arg1._1);
}

def reduce(arg0:(Int,Int)):(Int,Int) = {
	val denom = arg0._1 * arg0._2 / gcd(arg0);
	return (denom / arg0._2,denom / arg0._1);
}
def gcd(arg0:(Int,Int)):Int = {if(arg0._2 == 0) return arg0._1 else gcd((arg0._2,arg0._1 % arg0._2))}

} [/code]

EDIT: Changed it to use GCD like the rest of you.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:36, topic:547684”][quote author=Not_a_bot link=topic=666588.msg4459658#msg4459658 date=1416886053]

You are wrong though[/quote]
First, tell me exactly what is wrong in my first post, which is something The Enforcer might not have even checked now that I think about it.[/quote]

You already know what’s wrong though? Your initial code was fudgeed when it came to adding/subtracting fractions correctly (iirc all you did was add both the numerators and denominators like a retard). Other than that, he also pointed out that you were parsing inputs as doubles which wasn’t necessary. As far as code quality, it’s subjective and there are obviously other ways to approach this; regardless you already have proven to be wrong simply by admission.

Now stop circling this argument and just admit already that you’re wrong.
